title: 106_hr2309
content: The "Independent Medical Review Act of 1999" may be cited as the short title. Special rules apply to group health plans. Section 503 of ERISA is amended to include special rules for group health plans, requiring claims procedures to notify participants of their right to appeal adverse determinations to a utilization review agent. Notification to a participant or beneficiary of their right to appeal adverse determinations to a utilization review agent, independent review organization, and the procedures for appealing to an independent review organization. The curr_chunk discusses the procedures for a fair, de novo determination of medical necessity by an independent review organization without regard to the plan's definition. It also includes notification to a participant with a life-threatening condition of their right to immediate review by an independent review organization. The curr_chunk outlines the appeal process for a participant or beneficiary who has been denied benefits by an employee benefit plan. The appeal can be made orally or in writing by the participant, their representative, or their healthcare provider. The appeal process for denied benefits by an employee benefit plan allows the beneficiary, participant, or their healthcare provider to appeal orally or in writing. The utilization review agent must acknowledge receipt of the appeal within 5 working days and provide a list of required documents. The utilization review agent must send a one-page appeal form to the appealing party in cases of oral appeals of adverse determinations. Appeal decisions are made by a physician, but can be reviewed by a specialist if good cause is provided within 10 working days of denial. The expedited appeal procedure for emergency care denials includes a review by a health care provider of the same specialty within 15 working days. The expedited appeal process for emergency care denials requires a review by a care provider of the same specialty within one working day of receiving all necessary information. After seeking review, the utilization review agent must issue a response letter. The utilization review agent must issue a response letter to the appealing party, explaining the resolution of the appeal with specific medical reasons, clinical basis, and provider specialization. Written notification of appeal determination must be provided within 30 days. If an appeal is denied, independent review by an organization is allowed. The independent review process ensures timely response, confidentiality of medical records, and independence of healthcare providers. The independent review process guarantees the independence of healthcare providers making determinations and timely notification of results to the participant. The independent review organization must receive relevant medical records and documents from the utilization review agent within 3 business days of a request for review of an adverse determination. The independent review organization must receive relevant medical records, documents, written notification of denial, appeal documentation, and list of physicians involved in the review process. The independent review organization must make its determination within 15 days and receive relevant medical records and a list of physicians involved in the appeal process. The organization must make a determination within 15 days of receiving necessary information or within 20 days of receiving the request. The independent review organization must make a determination for a life-threatening condition within 5 days of receiving necessary information or within 8 days of receiving the request. The independent review organization must make a determination for a life-threatening condition within 5 days of receiving necessary information or within 8 days of receiving the request, and must be certified by the Secretary to be treated as an independent review organization. To be certified as an independent review organization by the Secretary, an organization must submit an annual application including details such as stockholders owning more than 5 percent of any stock or options, and the name and type of business. The applicant for certification as an independent review organization must disclose stockholders with more than 5 percent ownership, affiliated corporations, bond holders exceeding $100,000, and provide biographical information on directors, officers, and executives. The applicant must provide biographical information on directors, officers, and executives, including any relationships they have with health insurance providers, health maintenance organizations, utilization review agents, or nonprofit health organizations. The applicant must disclose relationships with various healthcare entities and the anticipated revenue from reviews conducted under this subsection. The applicant must disclose relationships with healthcare entities and anticipated revenue from reviews conducted under this subsection, including descriptions of expertise and procedures used by the independent review organization. The independent review determination is binding on the plan. The independent review determination is final and binding on the plan, and may only be vacated or modified by a court under specific circumstances. The independent review organization conducting a review under this section is not liable for damages arising from the determination made by the organization. The organization conducting a review is not liable for damages from the determination. Definitions include adverse determination and health care provider. The term 'health care provider' refers to individuals or entities in a State delivering health care services, required to be licensed or certified by State law. The term 'payor' refers to insurers writing health insurance policies or preferred provider organizations. A 'life-threatening condition' is a medical condition where death or serious bodily injury is likely without interruption of the disease or condition. The term 'payor' includes insurers, preferred provider organizations, and entities providing health benefits. A 'utilization review agent' conducts reviews for healthcare services. A utilization review agent conducts reviews for healthcare services for employers, payors, or administrators. The term 'working day' refers to a weekday excluding legal holidays.
